:''Main article: [[Criticism of Google]]''
:''Main article: [[Criticism of Google]]''
â
As it has grown, Google has found itself the focus of several controversies related to its business practices and services. For example, [[Google Book Search]]'s effort to digitize millions of books and make the full text searchable has led to [[copyright]] disputes with the [[Authors Guild]]. Google's cooperation with the governments of [[People's Republic of China|China]], and to a lesser extent [[France]] and [[Germany]] (regarding [[Holocaust denial]]) to filter search results in accordance to regional laws and regulations has led to claims of [[censorship by Google|censorship]]. Google's cooperation with the governments of [[People's Republic of China|China]], and to a lesser extent [[France]] and [[Germany]] (regarding [[Holocaust denial]]) to filter search results in accordance to regional laws and regulations has led to claims of [[censorship by Google|censorship]]. [[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] both have strongly condemned Google's China policy<ref>http://www.hrw.org/reports/2006/china0806/5.htm#_Toc142395827</ref>, calling it a form of self-censorship. According to Amnesty,
+
As it has grown, Google has found itself the focus of several controversies related to its business practices and services. For example, [[Google Book Search]]'s effort to digitize millions of books and make the full text searchable has led to [[copyright]] disputes with the [[Authors Guild]]. Google's cooperation with the governments of [[People's Republic of China|China]], and to a lesser extent [[France]] and [[Germany]] (regarding [[Holocaust denial]]) to filter search results in accordance to regional laws and regulations has led to claims of [[censorship by Google|censorship]]. [[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] both have strongly condemned Google's China policy<ref>http://www.hrw.org/reports/2006/china0806/5.htm#_Toc142395827</ref>, calling it a form of self-censorship. According to Amnesty,
<blockquote>
<blockquote>
[T]hese forms of censorship seem to contradict the very principles that Google - whose unofficial motto is "donât be evil" - was founded upon. Until January 2006, Google's Support Centre claimed that it "does not censor results for any search term", but removed this claim after reaching its deal with China.<ref>http://web.amnesty.org/pages/internet-110506-action-eng</ref>
[T]hese forms of censorship seem to contradict the very principles that Google - whose unofficial motto is "donât be evil" - was founded upon. Until January 2006, Google's Support Centre claimed that it "does not censor results for any search term", but removed this claim after reaching its deal with China.<ref>http://web.amnesty.org/pages/internet-110506-action-eng</ref>
